Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Modeling Social Interaction and Performance in STEM Learning

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Research on Education and Learning (REAL) project arises from an October 2014 Ideas Lab on Data-intensive Research to Improve Teaching and Learning. The intentions of that effort were to: (1) bring together researchers from across disciplines to foster novel, transformative, multidisciplinary approaches to using the data in large education-related data sets to create actionable knowledge for improving STEM teaching and learning environments in the medium term; and (2) revolutionize learning in the longer term. In this project, researchers from the Educational Testing Service, Columbia University Teachers' College, Arizona State University, and North Carolina State University will conduct data-driven, exploratory analyses to identify key places where social interactions impact learning outcomes in specific learning environments, with the goal of improving teaching and learning in large-scale STEM courses.

This research takes advantage of data traces left in large-scale blended and online learning environments (including massively open online courses, or MOOCs). The researchers will develop a comprehensive model for social learning in the context of such courses that will enable assessment of both the collaborative needs of individuals within the context of a class, and the quality of collaborations they are carrying out. Such diagnoses will allow both instructors and automated systems to provide advice to learners about the peers they might work with to enhance their learning (e.g., regarding the kinds of social interactions that will foster better understanding and development of important disciplinary capabilities). An interdisciplinary team of investigators with expertise in theory-driven educational data mining, natural-language processing, psychometrics, social-network analysis, and computer support for collaborative learning will collaborate to explore when learners in blended and online classes benefit from social interactions, and to understand how to identify more and less productive collaborative interactions. The researchers will use data from three blended and online classes (e.g., log files capturing collaborative discussions, individual and collaborative interactions around well-instrumented examples, peer tutoring sessions, pair programming labs, paired projects) and a variety of data analysis approaches (e.g., text analysis, machine learning) to determine: (1) which cognitive, social, and affective dimensions of need and interaction can be identified from available data; (2) which analyses are useful in providing action-oriented collaboration advice; and (3) what additional types of data may be needed for making such recommendations. This exploration will be grounded in theories of social interactions for learning (e.g., self-explanation, dialectic with oneself and others, zone of proximal development, social learning theory of Bandura, peripheral and centripetal participation).

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aimed to combine data streams from multiple sources of online course data to model social interaction among learners and the relationship between social interaction and academic performance.  Despite long-standing awareness that social interaction is an integral part of knowledge construction, efforts to study the role of social interaction in learning have traditionally been monodisciplinary and/or relegated to qualitative and small-scale methodologies. Data traces left by online learning environments, including massive open online courses (MOOCs), offer the potential for scaling up such analyses.

As part of this project we collected and curated rich multi-year corpora of student and course data from three distinct courses spread across two institutions and across multiple learning platforms.  This included three complete offerings of a MOOC on educational data mining offered by Teachers College Columbia University on two different platforms and two years of data on blended courses collected at North Carolina State University covering courses in Introductory Computer Science and Discrete Mathematics.  Our interdisciplinary team of researchers with specializations in natural language processing, discourse analysis, social network analysis, educational data mining, and psychometrics enabled the project to investigate these datasets from multiple perspectives, yielding insights on social learning, online and face to face classes, and instructional and educational technology design.

 

Intellectual merit This project resulted in several substantive and methodological findings. Using social network methods applied to question-and-answer forums, we found significant association between social connectedness and future engagement. Students? social relationships and cultural background appear to impact their use of online learning tools, as well as their ultimate course performance. Results from generative statistical network models indicate that while modalities of interaction differ significantly in the many types of course data, that certain results are quite general. For example, the hypothesis that students are more likely to respond to other students in a forum if they have been responded to in the past (a kind of pay-it-forward hypothesis) is confirmed across multiple data sets.

We have also shown that it is possible to apply rich textual analysis to students? online contributions to estimate their level of comprehension and future class behaviors. We confirmed the hypothesis that students who produce forum posts that are on topic, are more related to other posts, are more central to the conversation, and are more collaborative (as indicated by the cohesion network indices) will be more likely to complete a MOOC than those who are not. Moreover, these findings can be replicated across courses, course structures, and institutions. Further exploring socio-emotional dimensions of learning, we found that grit and goal orientation are associated with MOOC completion, with grit predicting course completion independently from intention to complete and with comparable strength.


Broader Impacts The methodological challenges illuminated by this project led to multi-year, community-building workshops at key conferences, for example on graph-based methods (G-EDM, 2015-2017) and on learning analytics methodology (LAKMLA, 2017-2019). NLP tools have been incorporated ReaderBench, and data have already been made available for analysis by researchers at other institutions who will continue to develop new insights. Collecting and curating our datasets led to important discoveries about the alignment and synthesis of transactional data across platforms and to the development of tools for data integration and anonymization that will facilitate future data analysis efforts. Some of these tools are being prepared for public use to facilitate research on automated student support for instructors in blended and online courses.
